questions.question: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with complaints of dizziness. On examination,pallor was present. She will be considered severely anemic if her hemoglobin is less than
Which of the following is the second most common pathological cause of anemia inpregnancy?
questions.explanation: The second most common pathological cause of anemia during pregnancy is anemia associatedwith chronic disease. The most common pathological cause of anemia during pregnancy is irondeficiency anemia.Women with chronic disorders may develop anemia for the first time during pregnancy. Causesinclude:• Chronic renal insufficiency - the most common cause. Recombinant erythropoietin is used fortreating anemia due to chronic renal failure.• Inflammatory bowel disease• Connective tissue disorders• Granulomatous infections•Malignant neoplasms• Rheumatoid arthritis•⚫ Chronic suppurative conditions.Note: The most common cause of anemia in pregnancy is physiological. It is normally seen duringpregnancy. This occurs due to the expansion of plasma volume by 30-40%. This increase is muchmore than the increase in red cell mass (20-30%) during pregnancy. This leadsto hemodilution and an apparent decrease in hemoglobin levels.

questions.question: What is the average maternal requirement of iron during a singleton pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Maternal requirement of iron during a singleton gestation averages close to 1000 mg.The average iron stores in a non-pregnant female is around 300 mg. This falls short of therequirement of iron during pregnancy which is 1000 mg. Hence iron supplementation isnecessary to prevent iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy. This also forms the basis forprophylactic iron supplementation during pregnancy.Note: The Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (FOGSI) states that the iron requirement inpregnancy is 840 mg, as about 160 mg of iron is saved due to amenorrhea during pregnancy.Iron requirement during pregnancyFetus and placenta300mg460Iron requirement during pregnancyExpansion of maternal hemoglobin mass500mgLosses through normal excretion routes200mgTotal1000mg

questions.question: You initiate iron and folic acid supplements for a woman at 13 weeks of gestation. Accordingto the ministry of health & family welfare (MOHFW), what is the minimum duration for454which she should take these supplements?
questions.explanation: The guideline recommends 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 µg of folic acid daily for at least 180days, starting from the 4th month of pregnancy, and to be continued throughoutpregnancy. Ideally, this must be continued until 180 days postpartum.

questions.question: Identify the correctly matched dose for folic acid supplementation that should be given inpregnant women with the following conditions?

options.B: Previous child with neural tube defect - 1 mg

questions.explanation: The amount of folic acid to be given to pregnant women suffering from sickle cell anemia is 5 mg.This is to reduce the risk of neural tube defects and to compensate for the increased demand forfolate during pregnancy.Normally in all sickle cell patients (irrespective of age or sex), 1mg of folic acid is given to preventfolate deficiency.Note: William's Obstetrics 26th Edition mentions folic acid 4 mg daily for pregnant women withsickle cell disease. However various other sources and RCOG guidelines mention it as 5 mg daily.Hence this is the best answer.

questions.question: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestation presented with insomnia due to a compulsiveurge to keep moving her legs. Blood tests revealed a Hb value of 10.1 g/dl. Which of thefollowing is the most sensitive indicator for her underlying condition?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, history suggestive of restless leg syndrome and Hb of 10.1g/dL points to adiagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. Serum ferritin is the most sensitive indicator of irondeficiency anemia in pregnant women.This is because its concentrations are not affected by the recent intake of iron-rich foods. Serumferritin concentration <15 µg/L indicates iron deficiency anemia.However, treatment needs to be initiated when the concentration falls <30 µg/L, as thisindicates early iron depletion.Restless leg syndrome also called Willis-Ekbom Disease, causes unpleasant or uncomfortablesensations in the legs along with an irresistible urge to move them. It may be associated with irondeficiency anemia.461

questions.question: A pregnant teacher presented with complaints of difficulty concentrating at work.Investigations revealed normal MCV with blood picture as shown below. What is the mostlikely diagnosis?455

options.B: Dimorphic anemiaSickle cell anaemiad) Folic acid deficiencyQuestion 8:A woman at 36 weeks of gestation was brought to the clinic by her concerned husband. Hementioned that over the last few weeks he noticed her chewing on cardboard pieces and icecream sticks on multiple occasions. On examination, pallor was present and Hb was 8.6 g/dl.What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?a) Ferrous sulfateb) Red cell transfusion

questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario presence of microcytic hypochromic RBCs indicates iron deficiencyanemia, and hyper segmented neutrophils indicate anemia due to folic acid or vitamin B12deficiency. This is also known as dimorphic anemia.Blood picture in iron deficiency anemia:Microcytic hypochromic RBCs• Typical photo pencil cells.• Presence of poikilocytes (pre-erythrocytes)•Blood picture in folic acid/vitamin B12 deficiency anemia:• Hyper segmented neutrophils - earliest changeMacrocytic RBCsDimorphic anaemia - iron deficiencyand folic acid deficiencyHyper-segmentedneutrophilMicrocytichypochromic RBCMacrocyte

questions.question: Which of the following is the most effective parenteral iron preparation prescribed forpostpartum women with iron deficiency anemia?
questions.explanation: Ferric carboxymaltose is considered superior to all other parenteral iron supplementationespecially for iron deficiency anemia in postpartum women.Ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) is a dextran-free IV iron preparation. It allows rapid administrationof high doses of iron (up to 1000 mg iron in 15 min).It is safe and effective in improving the mean Hb level. It avoids the need for blood transfusions.

questions.question: You have been asked to start parenteral iron infusion for a woman at 38 weeks of gestation.What formula would you use to calculate the required dosage?

options.B: × body weight (kg)b) 2.4 × (target Hb-actual Hb) × body weight (kg) + 500 mg
options.C: 2.4 × (target Hb-actual Hb) x body weight (kg) + 500 mcg.
options.D: 2.4 (target Hb-actual Hb) x body weight (kg) + 50 mg/kg

questions.explanation: The formula for calculating dose of parenteral iron is:Total dose in mg = 2.4 X (Target Hb - Actual Hb) X Body Wt. + 500 mg• 2.4 - conversion factor•Target Hb - Hb you want to achieve• Actual Hb- level of current Hb• 500 mg - additional amount to replenish the iron storesIron sucrose must be diluted only using normal saline at a concentration of 1-2 mg of iron/mL ofsaline. It is given over 20-30 minutes intravenously.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding parenteral iron therapy for iron deficiency anemia inpregnant women?

options.A: Can be given in first trimester
options.C: Sensitivity test is mandatory before administration
options.D: Can be given alongside oral iron therapy

questions.explanation: Parenteral iron therapy for iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy is avoided if the patient has ahistory of chronic liver disease.It is used as an alternative therapy in people who cannot tolerate oral iron.Contraindications include:• A history of prior anaphylactic reaction to parenteral iron therapy463•First trimester of pregnancy - there is no evidence on the use of IV iron in the first trimester ofpregnancy• Chronic liver disease• Active infection (acute or chronic)A sensitivity test prior to the infusion is not mandatory. IV iron should be given with caution evenif previous administrations have been well tolerated.Oral iron should be stopped at least 24 hours prior to therapy to avoid iron toxicity.

questions.question: A G3P2 female patient who is an agricultural laborer presents with complaints of fatigue at 36weeks of gestation. On examination, pallor and mild pedal edema are present. Herhemoglobin is 6.7 g/dl. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: The treatment of choice for severe anemia (< 7g/dL) in the third trimester is packed celltransfusion. It is preferred over whole blood as it avoids volume overload.Indications of blood transfusion in pregnancy include:.•Pregnancy <34 weeks• Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia• Hb 5-7 g/dL - in presence of impending heart failure• Pregnancy >34 weeks Hb <7 g/dL.

questions.question: A pregnant woman was brought by her husband after fainting at home. He gave a history ofher being clumsy and forgetful over the last few weeks. Investigations revealed high MCV457with hypersegmented neutrophils. How will you manage this patient?

options.B: 1000 µg of IM cyanocobalamin + folic acid

questions.explanation: The given scenario points to vitamin B12 deficiency. It is treated by vitamin B12 injections withfolic acid supplementation. 1000 µg of IM cyanocobalamin should be given initially every week for6 weeks, following which it should be given once every month.Megaloblastic anemia caused by Vit B12 deficiency should be identified and treated accordinglybecause folic acid supplementation alone will not help.Causes of Vit B12 deficiency leading to anemia in pregnancy:• Gastric resection• Addisonian pernicious anemia•• Crohn's disease• Ileal resection• Bacterial overgrowth in the small bowel.

questions.question: An anxious primigravida with sickle cell trait comes to you for her first antenatal checkup.Which of the following is she at a higher risk of developing during the course of thispregnancy?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, patients with sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing urinarytract infections.464Sickle cell disease, on the other hand, is associated with increased risk of:•Miscarriages•⚫ Fetal growth restriction• Preterm labor•· Venous thromboembolism• Pre-eclampsia•Placental abruption• Fetal distress in laborNote: Sickle cell trait is a benign condition in which the affected person has only one abnormalhemoglobin beta gene allele whereas, in sickle cell disease, the affected person has two abnormalhemoglobin beta gene alleles and is hence severely symptomatic. Unlike individuals with sicklecell disease, those with sickle cell trait do not have symptoms related to sickling and mostly lead anormal life.

questions.question: A sexually active woman with sickle cell anemia comes to the clinic for advice regardingcontraception. Which of the following is the ideal contraceptive for this patient?
questions.explanation: Low-dose oral progestins or progesterone injections or implants are ideal contraceptives in apatient with sickle cell anemia. Progesterone has been known to prevent painful sickle cell crises.It is considered very safe in pregnancy. It is rated level 1 indicating that there is no restriction intheir use.Contraceptive methods and their safety profile in sickle cell anemia:Level 1 contraceptives (no restriction):• Progestogen-only injection (DMPA)•⚫ Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Mirena)• Emergency contraception containing progestinsLevel 2 contraceptives (advantages outweigh disadvantages):••Combined oral contraceptive• Copper intrauterine device.

questions.question: A pregnant woman with thalassemia major presents to the clinic at 24 weeks of gestation withfatigue and shortness of breath. Which of the following is not true regarding the managementof this condition?

options.A: Parenteral iron therapy is the treatment of choice
options.C: Breast feeding is safe after delivery
options.D: Repeated transfusions are necessary to maintain Hb levels above 10 g/dl458

questions.explanation: In thalassemia major, both oral and parenteral iron preparations are avoided. This is becausethese patients are already in a state of iron overload due to multiple blood transfusions.Pregnancy in patients with thalassemia major is very rare. In case pregnancy occurs the followingstrategies are adopted:•• Iron chelating agents should be stopped465•5mg folic acid supplementation should be given daily• Pneumococcal vaccination and boosters are advised prior to pregnancy• Repeated blood transfusions are given to maintain Hb levels above 10 g/dL• Breastfeeding is safe and iron chelation therapy can be resumed post-delivery.466
